title: Review & setlist: Dropkick Murphys come on strong, avert disaster at soggy Suffolk Downs
author: Marc Hirsh
bullets: Dropkick Murphys performed at the Seisiún festival in Suffolk Downs, overcoming weather disruptions and engaging a dedicated crowd.
A severe thunderstorm delayed the festival, resulting in an evacuation and eventual return of concertgoers after a two-hour wait.
The band played a mix of hardcore punk and folk, featuring tributes and live debuts, concluding with 'I'm Shipping Up To Boston.'

title: Bill Belichick explains ‘simple’ reason why he decided to ban Patriots scout at UNC
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick banned a Patriots scout from North Carolina practices due to feeling unwelcome at their facility.
The UNC ban reflects ongoing tensions between Belichick and the Patriots since his departure in 2023.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel stated that they'll seek alternative ways to scout UNC players.

title: Raiders 20, Patriots 10 (4th): Vegas capitalizes off Maye INT
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Raiders defeated the Patriots 20-10 in their season opener at Gillette Stadium.
Patriots' Drake Maye threw a costly interception in the third quarter, leading to a Raiders touchdown.
Raiders' Daniel Carlson sealed the game with a field goal, making it 20-10 with under 7 minutes left.

title: Watch: Dropkick Murphys blast Trump, but stump for a longshot New England candidate
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Dropkick Murphys frontman Ken Casey criticized Donald Trump during their Seisiun festival performance in Boston.
Casey endorsed Graham Platner, a Marine Corps veteran and oyster farmer running for Senate in Maine.
Platner aims to challenge GOP Sen. Susan Collins and bring fresh perspectives to the Democratic Party.

title: Tenants move into first downtown apartment in Wu’s office-residential conversion program
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Boston's first office-to-residential conversion at 281 Franklin St. completed with 15 new apartments.
Mayor Wu supports the initiative, aiming to convert 700,000 square feet of office space into residential units.
Developer Adam Burns credits tax incentives for enabling project completion; concerns remain over high office vacancy rates.

title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Disciplinary cases at Harvard tripled during the 2023-2024 academic year due to pro-Palestine protests.
Over half of 90 disciplined students were accused of violating protest policies or participating in unsanctioned protests.
Five students initially suspended for protest involvement had suspensions reduced to probation by Harvard's Administrative Board.

title: Photos: Music, Guinness, and lots of rain at Day 1 of Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: The Seisiún Irish music festival kicked off at Suffolk Downs in Boston amid rain on Saturday, September 7, 2025.
Headliners included Dropkick Murphys, The Hold Steady, and The Scratch despite weather-related delays and evacuations.
Festival-goers enjoyed Guinness and performances wearing Irish flag-inspired attire while navigating rain delays.

title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman's retrospective exhibition is on display at Bates College Museum of Art in Lewiston, Maine, through October 11.
The exhibit features 149 pieces showcasing Steadman's career, including collaborations with Hunter S. Thompson.
Steadman recounts a 1970 event in Newport, Rhode Island, involving attempted yacht graffiti with Hunter S. Thompson.

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: About 40,000 adult SNAP recipients in Greater Boston may lose benefits under Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill.
The bill could strip SNAP eligibility from 9,600 legally present immigrants in Massachusetts.
Massachusetts may face a $58 million increase in SNAP administration costs due to federal requirement changes.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: New England Revolution lost 3-2 to the Chicago Fire, undermining their already slim playoff hopes.
Goals from Chicago's Jonathan Bamba and Philip Zinckernagel set an early lead against New England.
Revolution's coach Caleb Porter took responsibility for the defeat, admitting strategic errors and a lack of execution.
